captions.text: [Intro]

If you've ever taken an Intro to Biology class,
you might have noticed that there are some

pretty big but pretty basic things about your
own cells that never really get explained.

Or at least not explained well. Like, what
makes your cells divide when they copy themselves,

and how does stuff get carried from one part
of cell to another, and who's doing all the

carrying?
The answer to all of these questions and more

is a feat of biological engineering in which
a tiny peg-legged pirate walks microscopic

planks to carry cargo all around your cells.
Sorta.

The pirates are two-legged molecules called
motor proteins. Their job is to carry cellular

material wherever it's needed, whether it's
food or signaling molecules or genetic information.

And to get around, they use your cell's internal
highway system, known as the microtubule cytoskeleton.

This network of tiny tubes is what gives each
of your cells its unique structure. It's made

up of a protein called tubulin, and depending
on how it's arranged, it can form a cylindrical

stomach cell or a spiky nerve cell or a squashed
cell of connective tissue.

But day-to-day, second-by-second, its most
important role is serving as a kind of catwalk

for your motor proteins. A particularly delightful
kind of motor protein is kinesin, which looks

kind of like a little buccaneer swaggering
around with a giant beach ball head. Typical

kinesins have a head-like region up top, to
hold their cargo, followed by a coiled middle

region and two feet that literally walk along
the microtubule.

In order to move, each foot uses chemical
energy in the form of power-packed molecules

floating around in the cell called ATP. When
one foot grabs an ATP molecule that's passing

by, the foot changes shape and swings around
the central coil, flinging itself forward.

The other foot remains stuck to the microtubule,
so it won't fall off, and then it gets a zap

of energy from another ATP molecule and takes
a step, and the whole motor protein lurches

forward.
A typical kinesin motor can travel this way

at the rate of about one micrometer per second.
That's about 0.000002 miles per hour.

But those motors don't have to move very fast,
because cells aren't very big, right? Well,

most of them aren't. But the single nerve
cell that runs the length of your leg can

be up to a meter long. This is the nerve cell
that lets you move your leg, and it's the

job of the kinesins to constantly supply the
very end of that cell with neurotransmitters,

or messenger chemicals, so it can communicate
with your muscles.

A motor protein moving at an average pace
would take 11 and a half days to make this

meter long journey from the cell's nucleus,
where the cell's chemicals are made, all the

way to the ends. But these kinesins can do
it in as little as two or three days. Thanks

to them, your legs are always ready to run
when you need 'em.

And not only can motor proteins run along
microtubules, they can also, like, jog in

place as if they were on tiny treadmills,
and this is how your cells divide: by essentially

running in place, these proteins cause the
whole microtubule to roll along beneath them,

which helps wrench apart the splitting cells.
This is also how the chromosomes in the center

of the newly dividing cell get pulled toward
either end. Without these motor proteins running

in place, your genetic material wouldn't be
distributed correctly to the trillions of

new cells that you make every day.
So even though your textbook or your teacher

probably didn't tell you, now you know that
most of your cell's important functions happen

because of tiny swaggering bobble-headed pirates.
Thanks for joining us for this SciShow Dose.

To learn how you can help us keep exploring
the science inside you and everywhere else,

just go to Subbable.com/SciShow, and if you
want to keep getting smarter with us, don't
forget to go to YouTube.com/SciShow and subscribe.

title: Motor Proteins: Tiny Pirates in Your Cells

comments.text:
One of the pictures shown while explaining microtubules was actually a 
microfilament. Microfilaments are made up of actin, which spiral aroud each 
other without making a tubelike structure. As mentioned in the video, micro 
tubules are made up of tubulin. These are separate structures in the 
cellular cytoskeleton, but both of them have their own motorproteins. All 
the same, they're both pretty cool.﻿
comments.author: Cherie Jenkins

comments.text:
motor proteins don't just act on microtubules, myosin is a motor protein 
that acts on microfilaments which is made from actin rather than tubulin﻿

comments.text:
so, I get that you're going for brevity... but it bothers me that half of 
your examples are actin based myosin motors rather than tubulin based 
kinesins or dyneins.  In particular, cell fission comes from myosin 2 and 
bundled actin, NOT tubulin based motors.  Please don't over-simplify to the 
point of spreading mis-information.﻿

comments.author: Rick Rowland

comments.text:
Is "trillions" a semi-accurate number?  Or is the word "trillions" used in 
this video like the made up word "bajillions" is used?  We often take large 
number words like this for granted, so I'm just curious.﻿
comments.author: Darren Pope

comments.text:
+TheBrownieQueen Excellent point!  That's exactly my point!  People throw 
around the word "trillions" without really knowing what it means.  The 
national debt is something like 18 trillion...  If people actually 
understood just how big the number one trillion was, then they would be 
legitimately freaked out.  Instead, people hear and say the word trillion 
and they might as well be hearing "bajillions."  Which, as you said, is a 
made up word.

The fact that our body has 2 trillion cell divisions in a day is mind 
boggling.

I urge every reader to try to even put the number 1 billion in perspective. 
 Could you walk one billion steps in a life time?
comments.author: Darren Pope

comments.text:
After thousands, the numbers sort of follow a prefix kind of system million 
- mono, billion - bi, trillion - tri, quadrillion - quad, etc. Bajillion is 
just a made up word that sounds like the actual words. Either way, once you 
start getting into such high numbers it's hard to really comprehend the 
difference anymore.
comments.author: TheBrownieQueen

comments.text:
I googled it and found that there are, indeed, around 2 trillion cell

cells-divide.

comments.text:
Hank was right, basic cellular mechanics are glossed over too readily. I 
always pictured a molecular soup that worked based on proportions and 
proximity, like intra-cellular osmosis. This fundamentally changes my 
understanding of the cell. There's no reason why there shouldn't be at 
least a few paragraphs introducing these mechanics in every biology 
textbook out there, from middle school on up.﻿

it out and post your findings here! You should research how "radioactive 
dating" works, and summarize it. I think it has something to do with the 
half life of radioactive materials, and that the rate at which you can 
detect radioisotopes coming off a lump of stuff with uranium in it tells 
you how long it has already been giving off radioisotopes.

the best way because the solvents were toxic.  Thanks for the update.
comments.author: joeschultz2

comments.text: +Sean Breheny Wow thanks! :)
comments.author: TheSquishey

comments.text:
+TheSquishey I'm sure if you search for decaffeination you'll find 
something. I am pretty sure Ben Krasnow of the Applied Science Youtube 
channel has explained it in some of his videos. The basic method is that 
you use a solvent which dissolves caffeine but not the other stuff in 
coffee. Then, you mix the solvent and the coffee, let the solvent dissolve 
the caffeine, pulling it out of the coffee. Finally, you drain the solvent 
off and then let the residue of solvent evaporate. When they first began to 
decaffeinate coffee, they used organic solvents like benzene, which can be 
toxic if not completely removed. Now they use supercritical CO2 (CO2 in a 
temperature and pressure range where it has some properties of a liquid and 
some properties of a gas - it can diffuse into the coffee quickly, dissolve 
the caffeine, and then be sucked back out. Any residue of CO2 just turns to 
gas and leaves when the coffee is brough back to normal atmospheric 
pressure.
